feed.title: Combined summary - On mempool policy consistency

entry.title: Combined summary - On mempool policy consistency
entry.summary: The Bitcoin-dev community has been debating the possibility of allowing zero-confirmation transactions and the adoption of full replace-by-fee (fullrbf) policies. Some members argue that rational thieves would out-bid themselves to have funds come back to themselves in 0-conf services, while others believe that pinning transactions could be considered rational too as it allows those doing the pinning to steal funds from their counterparties by forcing a timeout to expire. The developers debated over whether they should support all use cases or not.There were concerns that enabling fullrbf would cause zero-conf services to go away, reducing mempool pressure and fee income from on-chain transactions. Some developers suggested maintaining a relay policy where replacements are rejected for transactions that do not opt-in to RBF and removing the `-mempoolfullrbf` flag from Bitcoin Core's latest release candidate. However, there is also a debate over whether miners adopting fullrbf would result in much additional fee income or if there is any evidence that miners even want this option.The article also discusses the limitations of opt-in Replace-By-Fee (RBF) and full RBF policies on the Bitcoin network. While a maximal RBF policy may be desirable for multiparty protocols like coinjoin, there are difficulties in designing such a policy that is resistant to denial-of-service attacks and ensures all desirable transactions are mined. In a recent email to the Bitcoin-dev mailing list, Suhas Daftuar discussed the potential risks of allowing multiple descendant v3 transactions. Daftuar argues that it is illogical for the recipient of a v3 transaction to believe that a sender's promise not to issue more high-value children descending from an unconfirmed transaction is fundamentally unenforceable. Daftuar also believes that it is inappropriate for Bitcoin Core to dictate policy on the network and that users should have the choice to turn off that flag if they desire.The conversation among multiple individuals revolves around Bitcoin Core's approach to relay/mempool policy. Previously, there was a single policy that worked for everyone, but now users have more options and can choose their own policies. Gradual deployments of mempool policies may present challenges such as compromising privacy and centralization, while recommending a mempool configuration outside of core could offer advantages such as easier adoption and no new mining centralization pressure.The fundamental goals of mempool/relay policy are to relay transactions for efficiency and privacy purposes and to have most of the data that makes up the next block pre-validated and pre-distributed throughout the network. However, there is increasing heterogeneity of Bitcoin applications and use-cases, which may require different service-level requirements in terms of latency, jitters, and bandwidth. One individual argues that decentralization/censorship-resistance, privacy, and efficiency are fundamental principles that should be prioritized over heterogeneity in policy rules, while another argues that more heterogeneity in policy rules usage makes more sense after exposure and exploration of more Bitcoin use-cases and applications.The email conversation also discusses the controversy surrounding the opt-in RBF feature in Bitcoin, which allows users to replace an unconfirmed transaction with a new one that pays a higher fee. The concern is that this feature could be used maliciously to double-spend coins and harm the network. There is debate over whether opt-in RBF is enough to prevent such attacks or if further changes are necessary.Overall, the conversations highlight the need for finding common ground and working together to address concerns about Bitcoin's mempool policy.
